Classes/AWSLexVoiceButton.html#/c:objc(c.name: animateOnImageSwitching
Classes/AWSLexVoiceButton.html#/c:objc(c.abstract: Enable push transition animation when image switch between microphone and listen image. Default is NO.

Classes/AWSLexVoiceButton.html#/c:objc(c.name: microphoneImageColor
Classes/AWSLexVoiceButton.html#/c:objc(c.abstract: Set color for microphone image. Default is nil.

Classes/AWSLexVoiceButton.html#/c:objc(c.name: lexImageColor
Classes/AWSLexVoiceButton.html#/c:objc(c.abstract: Set color for inactive microphone image. Default is light grey.

Classes/AWSLexVoiceButtonResponse.html#/.name: slots
Classes/AWSLexVoiceButtonResponse.html#/.abstract: The slots which are currently filled in an ongoing dialog

Classes/AWSLexVoiceButtonResponse.html#/.name: elicitSlot
Classes/AWSLexVoiceButtonResponse.html#/.abstract: The slot which is being ellicited for an intent.

Classes/AWSLexVoiceButtonResponse.html#/.name: sessionAttributes
Classes/AWSLexVoiceButtonResponse.html#/.abstract: The session attributes returned from the service.

Classes/AWSLexVoiceButtonResponse.html#/.name: audioStream
Classes/AWSLexVoiceButtonResponse.html#/.abstract: The audio stream . This may be null incase of a text response.

Classes/AWSLexVoiceButtonResponse.html#/.name: audioContentType
Classes/AWSLexVoiceButtonResponse.html#/.abstract: The format for the audio stream. This may be null if the audion stream is null.

Classes/AWSLexVoiceButtonResponse.html#/.name: inputTranscript
Classes/AWSLexVoiceButtonResponse.html#/.abstract: Transcript of the voice input to the operation.

Classes/AWSLex.html#/c:objc(cs)AWSLex(py.name: configuration
Classes/AWSLex.html#/c:objc(cs)AWSLex(py.abstract: The service configuration used to instantiate this service client.

Classes/AWSLex.html#/c:objc(cs)AWSLex(cm.name: +defaultLex
Classes/AWSLex.html#/c:objc(cs)AWSLex(cm.abstract: Returns the singleton service client. If the singleton object does not exist, the SDK instantiates the default service client with defaultServiceConfiguration from [AWSServiceManager defaultServiceManager]. The reference to this object is maintained by the SDK, and you do not need to retain it manually.

Classes/AWSLex.html#/c:objc(cs)AWSLex(cm.name: +registerLexWithConfiguration:forKey:
Classes/AWSLex.html#/c:objc(cs)AWSLex(cm.abstract: Creates a service client with the given service configuration and registers it for the key.

Classes/AWSLex.html#/c:objc(cs)AWSLex(cm.name: +LexForKey:
Classes/AWSLex.html#/c:objc(cs)AWSLex(cm.abstract: Retrieves the service client associated with the key. You need to call + registerLexWithConfiguration:forKey: before invoking this method.

Classes/AWSLex.html#/c:objc(cs)AWSLex(cm.name: +removeLexForKey:
Classes/AWSLex.html#/c:objc(cs)AWSLex(cm.abstract: Removes the service client associated with the key and release it.

Classes/AWSLex.html#/c:objc(cs)AWSLex(im.name: -deleteSession:
Classes/AWSLex.html#/c:objc(cs)AWSLex(im.abstract: Removes session information for a specified bot, alias, and user ID.

Classes/AWSLex.html#/c:objc(cs)AWSLex(im.name: -deleteSession:completionHandler:
Classes/AWSLex.html#/c:objc(cs)AWSLex(im.abstract: Removes session information for a specified bot, alias, and user ID.

Classes/AWSLex.html#/c:objc(cs)AWSLex(im.name: -getSession:
Classes/AWSLex.html#/c:objc(cs)AWSLex(im.abstract: Returns session information for a specified bot, alias, and user ID.

Classes/AWSLex.html#/c:objc(cs)AWSLex(im.name: -getSession:completionHandler:
Classes/AWSLex.html#/c:objc(cs)AWSLex(im.abstract: Returns session information for a specified bot, alias, and user ID.

Classes/AWSLex.html#/c:objc(cs)AWSLex(im.name: -postContent:
Classes/AWSLex.html#/c:objc(cs)AWSLex(im.abstract:
Sends user input (text or speech) to Amazon Lex. Clients use this API to send text and audio requests to Amazon Lex at runtime. Amazon Lex interprets the user input using the machine learning model that it built for the bot.

The PostContent operation supports audio input at 8kHz and 16kHz. You can use 8kHz audio to achieve higher speech recognition accuracy in telephone audio applications.

In response, Amazon Lex returns the next message to convey to the user. Consider the following example messages:

  • For a user input “I would like a pizza,” Amazon Lex might return a response with a message eliciting slot data (for example, PizzaSize): “What size pizza would you like?”.

  • After the user provides all of the pizza order information, Amazon Lex might return a response with a message to get user confirmation: “Order the pizza?”.

  • After the user replies “Yes” to the confirmation prompt, Amazon Lex might return a conclusion statement: “Thank you, your cheese pizza has been ordered.”.

Not all Amazon Lex messages require a response from the user. For example, conclusion statements do not require a response. Some messages require only a yes or no response. In addition to the message, Amazon Lex provides additional context about the message in the response that you can use to enhance client behavior, such as displaying the appropriate client user interface. Consider the following examples:

  • If the message is to elicit slot data, Amazon Lex returns the following context information:

    • x-amz-lex-dialog-state header set to ElicitSlot

    • x-amz-lex-intent-name header set to the intent name in the current context

    • x-amz-lex-slot-to-elicit header set to the slot name for which the message is eliciting information

    • x-amz-lex-slots header set to a map of slots configured for the intent with their current values

  • If the message is a confirmation prompt, the x-amz-lex-dialog-state header is set to Confirmation and the x-amz-lex-slot-to-elicit header is omitted.

  • If the message is a clarification prompt configured for the intent, indicating that the user intent is not understood, the x-amz-dialog-state header is set to ElicitIntent and the x-amz-slot-to-elicit header is omitted.

In addition, Amazon Lex also returns your application-specific sessionAttributes. For more information, see Managing Conversation Context.

Classes/AWSLex.html#/c:objc(cs)AWSLex(im.name: -postContent:completionHandler:
Classes/AWSLex.html#/c:objc(cs)AWSLex(im.abstract:
Sends user input (text or speech) to Amazon Lex. Clients use this API to send text and audio requests to Amazon Lex at runtime. Amazon Lex interprets the user input using the machine learning model that it built for the bot.

The PostContent operation supports audio input at 8kHz and 16kHz. You can use 8kHz audio to achieve higher speech recognition accuracy in telephone audio applications.

In response, Amazon Lex returns the next message to convey to the user. Consider the following example messages:

  • For a user input “I would like a pizza,” Amazon Lex might return a response with a message eliciting slot data (for example, PizzaSize): “What size pizza would you like?”.

  • After the user provides all of the pizza order information, Amazon Lex might return a response with a message to get user confirmation: “Order the pizza?”.

  • After the user replies “Yes” to the confirmation prompt, Amazon Lex might return a conclusion statement: “Thank you, your cheese pizza has been ordered.”.

Not all Amazon Lex messages require a response from the user. For example, conclusion statements do not require a response. Some messages require only a yes or no response. In addition to the message, Amazon Lex provides additional context about the message in the response that you can use to enhance client behavior, such as displaying the appropriate client user interface. Consider the following examples:

  • If the message is to elicit slot data, Amazon Lex returns the following context information:

    • x-amz-lex-dialog-state header set to ElicitSlot

    • x-amz-lex-intent-name header set to the intent name in the current context

    • x-amz-lex-slot-to-elicit header set to the slot name for which the message is eliciting information

    • x-amz-lex-slots header set to a map of slots configured for the intent with their current values

  • If the message is a confirmation prompt, the x-amz-lex-dialog-state header is set to Confirmation and the x-amz-lex-slot-to-elicit header is omitted.

  • If the message is a clarification prompt configured for the intent, indicating that the user intent is not understood, the x-amz-dialog-state header is set to ElicitIntent and the x-amz-slot-to-elicit header is omitted.

In addition, Amazon Lex also returns your application-specific sessionAttributes. For more information, see Managing Conversation Context.

Classes/AWSLex.html#/c:objc(cs)AWSLex(im.name: -postText:
Classes/AWSLex.html#/c:objc(cs)AWSLex(im.abstract:
Sends user input to Amazon Lex. Client applications can use this API to send requests to Amazon Lex at runtime. Amazon Lex then interprets the user input using the machine learning model it built for the bot.

In response, Amazon Lex returns the next message to convey to the user an optional responseCard to display. Consider the following example messages:

  • For a user input “I would like a pizza”, Amazon Lex might return a response with a message eliciting slot data (for example, PizzaSize): “What size pizza would you like?”

  • After the user provides all of the pizza order information, Amazon Lex might return a response with a message to obtain user confirmation “Proceed with the pizza order?”.

  • After the user replies to a confirmation prompt with a “yes”, Amazon Lex might return a conclusion statement: “Thank you, your cheese pizza has been ordered.”.

Not all Amazon Lex messages require a user response. For example, a conclusion statement does not require a response. Some messages require only a “yes” or “no” user response. In addition to the message, Amazon Lex provides additional context about the message in the response that you might use to enhance client behavior, for example, to display the appropriate client user interface. These are the slotToElicit, dialogState, intentName, and slots fields in the response. Consider the following examples:

  • If the message is to elicit slot data, Amazon Lex returns the following context information:

    • dialogState set to ElicitSlot

    • intentName set to the intent name in the current context

    • slotToElicit set to the slot name for which the message is eliciting information

    • slots set to a map of slots, configured for the intent, with currently known values

  • If the message is a confirmation prompt, the dialogState is set to ConfirmIntent and SlotToElicit is set to null.

  • If the message is a clarification prompt (configured for the intent) that indicates that user intent is not understood, the dialogState is set to ElicitIntent and slotToElicit is set to null.

In addition, Amazon Lex also returns your application-specific sessionAttributes. For more information, see Managing Conversation Context.

Classes/AWSLex.html#/c:objc(cs)AWSLex(im.name: -postText:completionHandler:
Classes/AWSLex.html#/c:objc(cs)AWSLex(im.abstract:
Sends user input to Amazon Lex. Client applications can use this API to send requests to Amazon Lex at runtime. Amazon Lex then interprets the user input using the machine learning model it built for the bot.

In response, Amazon Lex returns the next message to convey to the user an optional responseCard to display. Consider the following example messages:

  • For a user input “I would like a pizza”, Amazon Lex might return a response with a message eliciting slot data (for example, PizzaSize): “What size pizza would you like?”

  • After the user provides all of the pizza order information, Amazon Lex might return a response with a message to obtain user confirmation “Proceed with the pizza order?”.

  • After the user replies to a confirmation prompt with a “yes”, Amazon Lex might return a conclusion statement: “Thank you, your cheese pizza has been ordered.”.

Not all Amazon Lex messages require a user response. For example, a conclusion statement does not require a response. Some messages require only a “yes” or “no” user response. In addition to the message, Amazon Lex provides additional context about the message in the response that you might use to enhance client behavior, for example, to display the appropriate client user interface. These are the slotToElicit, dialogState, intentName, and slots fields in the response. Consider the following examples:

  • If the message is to elicit slot data, Amazon Lex returns the following context information:

    • dialogState set to ElicitSlot

    • intentName set to the intent name in the current context

    • slotToElicit set to the slot name for which the message is eliciting information

    • slots set to a map of slots, configured for the intent, with currently known values

  • If the message is a confirmation prompt, the dialogState is set to ConfirmIntent and SlotToElicit is set to null.

  • If the message is a clarification prompt (configured for the intent) that indicates that user intent is not understood, the dialogState is set to ElicitIntent and slotToElicit is set to null.

In addition, Amazon Lex also returns your application-specific sessionAttributes. For more information, see Managing Conversation Context.

Classes/AWSLex.html#/c:objc(cs)AWSLex(im.name: -putSession:
Classes/AWSLex.html#/c:objc(cs)AWSLex(im.abstract:
Creates a new session or modifies an existing session with an Amazon Lex bot. Use this operation to enable your application to set the state of the bot.

For more information, see Managing Sessions.

Classes/AWSLex.html#/c:objc(cs)AWSLex(im.name: -putSession:completionHandler:
Classes/AWSLex.html#/c:objc(cs)AWSLex(im.abstract:
Creates a new session or modifies an existing session with an Amazon Lex bot. Use this operation to enable your application to set the state of the bot.

For more information, see Managing Sessions.

Classes/AWSLexSentimentResponse.html#/c:.name: sentimentLabel
Classes/AWSLexSentimentResponse.html#/c:.abstract: The inferred sentiment that Amazon Comprehend has the highest confidence in.

Classes/AWSLexSentimentResponse.html#/c:.name: sentimentScore
Classes/AWSLexSentimentResponse.html#/c:.abstract: The likelihood that the sentiment was correctly inferred.

Classes/AWSLexResponseCard.html#/c:objc(.name: genericAttachments
Classes/AWSLexResponseCard.html#/c:objc(.abstract: An array of attachment objects representing options.

Classes/AWSLexResponseCard.html#/c:objc(.name: version
Classes/AWSLexResponseCard.html#/c:objc(.abstract: The version of the response card format.

Classes/AWSLexPutSessionResponse.html#/c.name: audioStream
Classes/AWSLexPutSessionResponse.html#/c.abstract: The audio version of the message to convey to the user.

Classes/AWSLexPutSessionResponse.html#/c.name: contentType
Classes/AWSLexPutSessionResponse.html#/c.abstract: Content type as specified in the Accept HTTP header in the request.

Classes/AWSLexPutSessionResponse.html#/c.name: dialogState
Classes/AWSLexPutSessionResponse.html#/c.abstract:
• ConfirmIntent - Amazon Lex is expecting a “yes” or “no” response to confirm the intent before fulfilling an intent.

  • ElicitIntent - Amazon Lex wants to elicit the user’s intent.

  • ElicitSlot - Amazon Lex is expecting the value of a slot for the current intent.

  • Failed - Conveys that the conversation with the user has failed. This can happen for various reasons, including the user does not provide an appropriate response to prompts from the service, or if the Lambda function fails to fulfill the intent.

  • Fulfilled - Conveys that the Lambda function has sucessfully fulfilled the intent.

  • ReadyForFulfillment - Conveys that the client has to fulfill the intent.

Classes/AWSLexPutSessionResponse.html#/c.name: message
Classes/AWSLexPutSessionResponse.html#/c.abstract: The next message that should be presented to the user.

Classes/AWSLexPutSessionResponse.html#/c.name: messageFormat
Classes/AWSLexPutSessionResponse.html#/c.abstract:
The format of the response message. One of the following values:

  • PlainText - The message contains plain UTF-8 text.

  • CustomPayload - The message is a custom format for the client.

  • SSML - The message contains text formatted for voice output.

  • Composite - The message contains an escaped JSON object containing one or more messages from the groups that messages were assigned to when the intent was created.

Classes/AWSLexPutSessionResponse.html#/c.name: sessionAttributes
Classes/AWSLexPutSessionResponse.html#/c.abstract: Map of key/value pairs representing session-specific context information.

Classes/AWSLexPutSessionResponse.html#/c.name: slotToElicit
Classes/AWSLexPutSessionResponse.html#/c.abstract: If the dialogState is ElicitSlot, returns the name of the slot for which Amazon Lex is eliciting a value.

Classes/AWSLexPutSessionResponse.html#/c.name: slots
Classes/AWSLexPutSessionResponse.html#/c.abstract:
Map of zero or more intent slots Amazon Lex detected from the user input during the conversation.

Amazon Lex creates a resolution list containing likely values for a slot. The value that it returns is determined by the valueSelectionStrategy selected when the slot type was created or updated. If valueSelectionStrategy is set to ORIGINAL_VALUE, the value provided by the user is returned, if the user value is similar to the slot values. If valueSelectionStrategy is set to TOP_RESOLUTION Amazon Lex returns the first value in the resolution list or, if there is no resolution list, null. If you don’t specify a valueSelectionStrategy the default is ORIGINAL_VALUE.

Classes/AWSLexPutSessionRequest.html#/c:.name: accept
Classes/AWSLexPutSessionRequest.html#/c:.abstract:
The message that Amazon Lex returns in the response can be either text or speech based depending on the value of this field.

  • If the value is text/plain; charset=utf-8, Amazon Lex returns text in the response.

  • If the value begins with audio/, Amazon Lex returns speech in the response. Amazon Lex uses Amazon Polly to generate the speech in the configuration that you specify. For example, if you specify audio/mpeg as the value, Amazon Lex returns speech in the MPEG format.

  • If the value is audio/pcm, the speech is returned as audio/pcm in 16-bit, little endian format.

  • The following are the accepted values:

    • audio/mpeg

    • audio/ogg

    • audio/pcm

    • audio/* (defaults to mpeg)

    • text/plain; charset=utf-8

Classes/AWSLexPutSessionRequest.html#/c:.name: botAlias
Classes/AWSLexPutSessionRequest.html#/c:.abstract: The alias in use for the bot that contains the session data.

Classes/AWSLexPutSessionRequest.html#/c:.name: botName
Classes/AWSLexPutSessionRequest.html#/c:.abstract: The name of the bot that contains the session data.

Classes/AWSLexPutSessionRequest.html#/c:.name: dialogAction
Classes/AWSLexPutSessionRequest.html#/c:.abstract: Sets the next action that the bot should take to fulfill the conversation.

Classes/AWSLexPutSessionRequest.html#/c:.name: recentIntentSummaryView
Classes/AWSLexPutSessionRequest.html#/c:.abstract:
A summary of the recent intents for the bot. You can use the intent summary view to set a checkpoint label on an intent and modify attributes of intents. You can also use it to remove or add intent summary objects to the list.

An intent that you modify or add to the list must make sense for the bot. For example, the intent name must be valid for the bot. You must provide valid values for:

  • intentName

  • slot names

  • slotToElict

If you send the recentIntentSummaryView parameter in a PutSession request, the contents of the new summary view replaces the old summary view. For example, if a GetSession request returns three intents in the summary view and you call PutSession with one intent in the summary view, the next call to GetSession will only return one intent.

Classes/AWSLexPutSessionRequest.html#/c:.name: sessionAttributes
Classes/AWSLexPutSessionRequest.html#/c:.abstract: Map of key/value pairs representing the session-specific context information. It contains application information passed between Amazon Lex and a client application.

Classes/AWSLexPutSessionRequest.html#/c:.name: userId
Classes/AWSLexPutSessionRequest.html#/c:.abstract: The ID of the client application user. Amazon Lex uses this to identify a user’s conversation with your bot.

Classes/AWSLexPostTextResponse.html#/c:o.name: dialogState
Classes/AWSLexPostTextResponse.html#/c:o.abstract:
Identifies the current state of the user interaction. Amazon Lex returns one of the following values as dialogState. The client can optionally use this information to customize the user interface.

  • ElicitIntent - Amazon Lex wants to elicit user intent.

    For example, a user might utter an intent (“I want to order a pizza”). If Amazon Lex cannot infer the user intent from this utterance, it will return this dialogState.

  • ConfirmIntent - Amazon Lex is expecting a “yes” or “no” response.

    For example, Amazon Lex wants user confirmation before fulfilling an intent.

    Instead of a simple “yes” or “no,” a user might respond with additional information. For example, “yes, but make it thick crust pizza” or “no, I want to order a drink”. Amazon Lex can process such additional information (in these examples, update the crust type slot value, or change intent from OrderPizza to OrderDrink).

  • ElicitSlot - Amazon Lex is expecting a slot value for the current intent.

    For example, suppose that in the response Amazon Lex sends this message: “What size pizza would you like?”. A user might reply with the slot value (e.g., “medium”). The user might also provide additional information in the response (e.g., “medium thick crust pizza”). Amazon Lex can process such additional information appropriately.

  • Fulfilled - Conveys that the Lambda function configured for the intent has successfully fulfilled the intent.

  • ReadyForFulfillment - Conveys that the client has to fulfill the intent.

  • Failed - Conveys that the conversation with the user failed.

    This can happen for various reasons including that the user did not provide an appropriate response to prompts from the service (you can configure how many times Amazon Lex can prompt a user for specific information), or the Lambda function failed to fulfill the intent.

Classes/AWSLexPostTextResponse.html#/c:o.name: intentName
Classes/AWSLexPostTextResponse.html#/c:o.abstract: The current user intent that Amazon Lex is aware of.

Classes/AWSLexPostTextResponse.html#/c:o.name: message
Classes/AWSLexPostTextResponse.html#/c:o.abstract:
The message to convey to the user. The message can come from the bot’s configuration or from a Lambda function.

If the intent is not configured with a Lambda function, or if the Lambda function returned Delegate as the dialogAction.type its response, Amazon Lex decides on the next course of action and selects an appropriate message from the bot’s configuration based on the current interaction context. For example, if Amazon Lex isn’t able to understand user input, it uses a clarification prompt message.

When you create an intent you can assign messages to groups. When messages are assigned to groups Amazon Lex returns one message from each group in the response. The message field is an escaped JSON string containing the messages. For more information about the structure of the JSON string returned, see msg-prompts-formats.

If the Lambda function returns a message, Amazon Lex passes it to the client in its response.

Classes/AWSLexPostTextResponse.html#/c:o.name: messageFormat
Classes/AWSLexPostTextResponse.html#/c:o.abstract:
The format of the response message. One of the following values:

  • PlainText - The message contains plain UTF-8 text.

  • CustomPayload - The message is a custom format defined by the Lambda function.

  • SSML - The message contains text formatted for voice output.

  • Composite - The message contains an escaped JSON object containing one or more messages from the groups that messages were assigned to when the intent was created.

Classes/AWSLexPostTextResponse.html#/c:o.name: responseCard
Classes/AWSLexPostTextResponse.html#/c:o.abstract: Represents the options that the user has to respond to the current prompt. Response Card can come from the bot configuration (in the Amazon Lex console, choose the settings button next to a slot) or from a code hook (Lambda function).

Classes/AWSLexPostTextResponse.html#/c:o.name: sentimentResponse
Classes/AWSLexPostTextResponse.html#/c:o.abstract:
The sentiment expressed in and utterance.

When the bot is configured to send utterances to Amazon Comprehend for sentiment analysis, this field contains the result of the analysis.

Classes/AWSLexPostTextResponse.html#/c:o.name: sessionAttributes
Classes/AWSLexPostTextResponse.html#/c:o.abstract: A map of key-value pairs representing the session-specific context information.

Classes/AWSLexPostTextResponse.html#/c:o.name: slotToElicit
Classes/AWSLexPostTextResponse.html#/c:o.abstract: If the dialogState value is ElicitSlot, returns the name of the slot for which Amazon Lex is eliciting a value.

Classes/AWSLexPostTextResponse.html#/c:o.name: slots
Classes/AWSLexPostTextResponse.html#/c:o.abstract:
The intent slots that Amazon Lex detected from the user input in the conversation.

Amazon Lex creates a resolution list containing likely values for a slot. The value that it returns is determined by the valueSelectionStrategy selected when the slot type was created or updated. If valueSelectionStrategy is set to ORIGINAL_VALUE, the value provided by the user is returned, if the user value is similar to the slot values. If valueSelectionStrategy is set to TOP_RESOLUTION Amazon Lex returns the first value in the resolution list or, if there is no resolution list, null. If you don’t specify a valueSelectionStrategy, the default is ORIGINAL_VALUE.

Classes/AWSLexPostTextRequest.html#/c:ob.name: botAlias
Classes/AWSLexPostTextRequest.html#/c:ob.abstract: The alias of the Amazon Lex bot.

Classes/AWSLexPostTextRequest.html#/c:ob.name: botName
Classes/AWSLexPostTextRequest.html#/c:ob.abstract: The name of the Amazon Lex bot.

Classes/AWSLexPostTextRequest.html#/c:ob.name: inputText
Classes/AWSLexPostTextRequest.html#/c:ob.abstract: The text that the user entered (Amazon Lex interprets this text).

Classes/AWSLexPostTextRequest.html#/c:ob.name: requestAttributes
Classes/AWSLexPostTextRequest.html#/c:ob.abstract:
Request-specific information passed between Amazon Lex and a client application.

The namespace x-amz-lex: is reserved for special attributes. Don’t create any request attributes with the prefix x-amz-lex:.

For more information, see Setting Request Attributes.

Classes/AWSLexPostTextRequest.html#/c:ob.name: sessionAttributes
Classes/AWSLexPostTextRequest.html#/c:ob.abstract:
Application-specific information passed between Amazon Lex and a client application.

For more information, see Setting Session Attributes.

Classes/AWSLexPostTextRequest.html#/c:ob.name: userId
Classes/AWSLexPostTextRequest.html#/c:ob.abstract:
The ID of the client application user. Amazon Lex uses this to identify a user’s conversation with your bot. At runtime, each request must contain the userID field.

To decide the user ID to use for your application, consider the following factors.

  • The userID field must not contain any personally identifiable information of the user, for example, name, personal identification numbers, or other end user personal information.

  • If you want a user to start a conversation on one device and continue on another device, use a user-specific identifier.

  • If you want the same user to be able to have two independent conversations on two different devices, choose a device-specific identifier.

  • A user can’t have two independent conversations with two different versions of the same bot. For example, a user can’t have a conversation with the PROD and BETA versions of the same bot. If you anticipate that a user will need to have conversation with two different versions, for example, while testing, include the bot alias in the user ID to separate the two conversations.

Classes/AWSLexPostContentResponse.html#/.name: audioStream
Classes/AWSLexPostContentResponse.html#/.abstract: The prompt (or statement) to convey to the user. This is based on the bot configuration and context. For example, if Amazon Lex did not understand the user intent, it sends the clarificationPrompt configured for the bot. If the intent requires confirmation before taking the fulfillment action, it sends the confirmationPrompt. Another example: Suppose that the Lambda function successfully fulfilled the intent, and sent a message to convey to the user. Then Amazon Lex sends that message in the response.

Classes/AWSLexPostContentResponse.html#/.name: contentType
Classes/AWSLexPostContentResponse.html#/.abstract: Content type as specified in the Accept HTTP header in the request.

Classes/AWSLexPostContentResponse.html#/.name: dialogState
Classes/AWSLexPostContentResponse.html#/.abstract:
Identifies the current state of the user interaction. Amazon Lex returns one of the following values as dialogState. The client can optionally use this information to customize the user interface.

  • ElicitIntent - Amazon Lex wants to elicit the user’s intent. Consider the following examples:

    For example, a user might utter an intent (“I want to order a pizza”). If Amazon Lex cannot infer the user intent from this utterance, it will return this dialog state.

  • ConfirmIntent - Amazon Lex is expecting a “yes” or “no” response.

    For example, Amazon Lex wants user confirmation before fulfilling an intent. Instead of a simple “yes” or “no” response, a user might respond with additional information. For example, “yes, but make it a thick crust pizza” or “no, I want to order a drink.” Amazon Lex can process such additional information (in these examples, update the crust type slot or change the intent from OrderPizza to OrderDrink).

  • ElicitSlot - Amazon Lex is expecting the value of a slot for the current intent.

    For example, suppose that in the response Amazon Lex sends this message: “What size pizza would you like?”. A user might reply with the slot value (e.g., “medium”). The user might also provide additional information in the response (e.g., “medium thick crust pizza”). Amazon Lex can process such additional information appropriately.

  • Fulfilled - Conveys that the Lambda function has successfully fulfilled the intent.

  • ReadyForFulfillment - Conveys that the client has to fulfill the request.

  • Failed - Conveys that the conversation with the user failed.

    This can happen for various reasons, including that the user does not provide an appropriate response to prompts from the service (you can configure how many times Amazon Lex can prompt a user for specific information), or if the Lambda function fails to fulfill the intent.

Classes/AWSLexPostContentResponse.html#/.name: inputTranscript
Classes/AWSLexPostContentResponse.html#/.abstract:
The text used to process the request.

If the input was an audio stream, the inputTranscript field contains the text extracted from the audio stream. This is the text that is actually processed to recognize intents and slot values. You can use this information to determine if Amazon Lex is correctly processing the audio that you send.

Classes/AWSLexPostContentResponse.html#/.name: intentName
Classes/AWSLexPostContentResponse.html#/.abstract: Current user intent that Amazon Lex is aware of.

Classes/AWSLexPostContentResponse.html#/.name: message
Classes/AWSLexPostContentResponse.html#/.abstract:
The message to convey to the user. The message can come from the bot’s configuration or from a Lambda function.

If the intent is not configured with a Lambda function, or if the Lambda function returned Delegate as the dialogAction.type in its response, Amazon Lex decides on the next course of action and selects an appropriate message from the bot’s configuration based on the current interaction context. For example, if Amazon Lex isn’t able to understand user input, it uses a clarification prompt message.

When you create an intent you can assign messages to groups. When messages are assigned to groups Amazon Lex returns one message from each group in the response. The message field is an escaped JSON string containing the messages. For more information about the structure of the JSON string returned, see msg-prompts-formats.

If the Lambda function returns a message, Amazon Lex passes it to the client in its response.

Classes/AWSLexPostContentResponse.html#/.name: messageFormat
Classes/AWSLexPostContentResponse.html#/.abstract:
The format of the response message. One of the following values:

  • PlainText - The message contains plain UTF-8 text.

  • CustomPayload - The message is a custom format for the client.

  • SSML - The message contains text formatted for voice output.

  • Composite - The message contains an escaped JSON object containing one or more messages from the groups that messages were assigned to when the intent was created.

Classes/AWSLexPostContentResponse.html#/.name: sentimentResponse
Classes/AWSLexPostContentResponse.html#/.abstract:
The sentiment expressed in and utterance.

When the bot is configured to send utterances to Amazon Comprehend for sentiment analysis, this field contains the result of the analysis.

Classes/AWSLexPostContentResponse.html#/.name: sessionAttributes
Classes/AWSLexPostContentResponse.html#/.abstract: Map of key/value pairs representing the session-specific context information.

Classes/AWSLexPostContentResponse.html#/.name: slotToElicit
Classes/AWSLexPostContentResponse.html#/.abstract: If the dialogState value is ElicitSlot, returns the name of the slot for which Amazon Lex is eliciting a value.

Classes/AWSLexPostContentResponse.html#/.name: slots
Classes/AWSLexPostContentResponse.html#/.abstract:
Map of zero or more intent slots (name/value pairs) Amazon Lex detected from the user input during the conversation. The field is base-64 encoded.

Amazon Lex creates a resolution list containing likely values for a slot. The value that it returns is determined by the valueSelectionStrategy selected when the slot type was created or updated. If valueSelectionStrategy is set to ORIGINAL_VALUE, the value provided by the user is returned, if the user value is similar to the slot values. If valueSelectionStrategy is set to TOP_RESOLUTION Amazon Lex returns the first value in the resolution list or, if there is no resolution list, null. If you don’t specify a valueSelectionStrategy, the default is ORIGINAL_VALUE.

Classes/AWSLexPostContentRequest.html#/c.name: accept
Classes/AWSLexPostContentRequest.html#/c.abstract:
You pass this value as the Accept HTTP header.

The message Amazon Lex returns in the response can be either text or speech based on the Accept HTTP header value in the request.

  • If the value is text/plain; charset=utf-8, Amazon Lex returns text in the response.

  • If the value begins with audio/, Amazon Lex returns speech in the response. Amazon Lex uses Amazon Polly to generate the speech (using the configuration you specified in the Accept header). For example, if you specify audio/mpeg as the value, Amazon Lex returns speech in the MPEG format.

  • If the value is audio/pcm, the speech returned is audio/pcm in 16-bit, little endian format.

  • The following are the accepted values:

    • audio/mpeg

    • audio/ogg

    • audio/pcm

    • text/plain; charset=utf-8

    • audio/* (defaults to mpeg)

Classes/AWSLexPostContentRequest.html#/c.name: contentType
Classes/AWSLexPostContentRequest.html#/c.abstract:
You pass this value as the Content-Type HTTP header.

Indicates the audio format or text. The header value must start with one of the following prefixes:

  • PCM format, audio data must be in little-endian byte order.

    • audio/l16; rate=16000; channels=1

    • audio/x-l16; sample-rate=16000; channel-count=1

    • audio/lpcm; sample-rate=8000; sample-size-bits=16; channel-count=1; is-big-endian=false

  • Opus format

    • audio/x-cbr-opus-with-preamble; preamble-size=0; bit-rate=256000; frame-size-milliseconds=4

  • Text format

    • text/plain; charset=utf-8

Classes/AWSLexPostContentRequest.html#/c.name: inputStream
Classes/AWSLexPostContentRequest.html#/c.abstract:
User input in PCM or Opus audio format or text format as described in the Content-Type HTTP header.

You can stream audio data to Amazon Lex or you can create a local buffer that captures all of the audio data before sending. In general, you get better performance if you stream audio data rather than buffering the data locally.

Classes/AWSLexPostContentRequest.html#/c.name: requestAttributes
Classes/AWSLexPostContentRequest.html#/c.abstract:
You pass this value as the x-amz-lex-request-attributes HTTP header.

Request-specific information passed between Amazon Lex and a client application. The value must be a JSON serialized and base64 encoded map with string keys and values. The total size of the requestAttributes and sessionAttributes headers is limited to 12 KB.

The namespace x-amz-lex: is reserved for special attributes. Don’t create any request attributes with the prefix x-amz-lex:.

For more information, see Setting Request Attributes.

Classes/AWSLexPostContentRequest.html#/c.name: sessionAttributes
Classes/AWSLexPostContentRequest.html#/c.abstract:
You pass this value as the x-amz-lex-session-attributes HTTP header.

Application-specific information passed between Amazon Lex and a client application. The value must be a JSON serialized and base64 encoded map with string keys and values. The total size of the sessionAttributes and requestAttributes headers is limited to 12 KB.

For more information, see Setting Session Attributes.

Classes/AWSLexPostContentRequest.html#/c.name: userId
Classes/AWSLexPostContentRequest.html#/c.abstract:
The ID of the client application user. Amazon Lex uses this to identify a user’s conversation with your bot. At runtime, each request must contain the userID field.

To decide the user ID to use for your application, consider the following factors.

  • The userID field must not contain any personally identifiable information of the user, for example, name, personal identification numbers, or other end user personal information.

  • If you want a user to start a conversation on one device and continue on another device, use a user-specific identifier.

  • If you want the same user to be able to have two independent conversations on two different devices, choose a device-specific identifier.

  • A user can’t have two independent conversations with two different versions of the same bot. For example, a user can’t have a conversation with the PROD and BETA versions of the same bot. If you anticipate that a user will need to have conversation with two different versions, for example, while testing, include the bot alias in the user ID to separate the two conversations.

Classes/AWSLexIntentSummary.html#/c:objc.name: checkpointLabel
Classes/AWSLexIntentSummary.html#/c:objc.abstract:
A user-defined label that identifies a particular intent. You can use this label to return to a previous intent.

Use the checkpointLabelFilter parameter of the GetSessionRequest operation to filter the intents returned by the operation to those with only the specified label.

Classes/AWSLexIntentSummary.html#/c:objc.name: confirmationStatus
Classes/AWSLexIntentSummary.html#/c:objc.abstract:
The status of the intent after the user responds to the confirmation prompt. If the user confirms the intent, Amazon Lex sets this field to Confirmed. If the user denies the intent, Amazon Lex sets this value to Denied. The possible values are:

  • Confirmed - The user has responded “Yes” to the confirmation prompt, confirming that the intent is complete and that it is ready to be fulfilled.

  • Denied - The user has responded “No” to the confirmation prompt.

  • None - The user has never been prompted for confirmation; or, the user was prompted but did not confirm or deny the prompt.

Classes/AWSLexIntentSummary.html#/c:objc.name: dialogActionType
Classes/AWSLexIntentSummary.html#/c:objc.abstract:
The next action that the bot should take in its interaction with the user. The possible values are:

  • ConfirmIntent - The next action is asking the user if the intent is complete and ready to be fulfilled. This is a yes/no question such as “Place the order?”

  • Close - Indicates that the there will not be a response from the user. For example, the statement “Your order has been placed” does not require a response.

  • ElicitIntent - The next action is to determine the intent that the user wants to fulfill.

  • ElicitSlot - The next action is to elicit a slot value from the user.

Classes/AWSLexIntentSummary.html#/c:objc.name: fulfillmentState
Classes/AWSLexIntentSummary.html#/c:objc.abstract:
The fulfillment state of the intent. The possible values are:

  • Failed - The Lambda function associated with the intent failed to fulfill the intent.

  • Fulfilled - The intent has fulfilled by the Lambda function associated with the intent.

  • ReadyForFulfillment - All of the information necessary for the intent is present and the intent ready to be fulfilled by the client application.

Classes/AWSLexIntentSummary.html#/c:objc.name: slotToElicit
Classes/AWSLexIntentSummary.html#/c:objc.abstract: The next slot to elicit from the user. If there is not slot to elicit, the field is blank.

Classes/AWSLexIntentSummary.html#/c:objc.name: slots
Classes/AWSLexIntentSummary.html#/c:objc.abstract: Map of the slots that have been gathered and their values.

Classes/AWSLexGetSessionResponse.html#/c.name: dialogAction
Classes/AWSLexGetSessionResponse.html#/c.abstract: Describes the current state of the bot.

Classes/AWSLexGetSessionResponse.html#/c.name: recentIntentSummaryView
Classes/AWSLexGetSessionResponse.html#/c.abstract:
An array of information about the intents used in the session. The array can contain a maximum of three summaries. If more than three intents are used in the session, the recentIntentSummaryView operation contains information about the last three intents used.

If you set the checkpointLabelFilter parameter in the request, the array contains only the intents with the specified label.

Classes/AWSLexGetSessionResponse.html#/c.name: sessionAttributes
Classes/AWSLexGetSessionResponse.html#/c.abstract: Map of key/value pairs representing the session-specific context information. It contains application information passed between Amazon Lex and a client application.

Classes/AWSLexGetSessionRequest.html#/c:.name: botAlias
Classes/AWSLexGetSessionRequest.html#/c:.abstract: The alias in use for the bot that contains the session data.

Classes/AWSLexGetSessionRequest.html#/c:.name: botName
Classes/AWSLexGetSessionRequest.html#/c:.abstract: The name of the bot that contains the session data.

Classes/AWSLexGetSessionRequest.html#/c:.name: checkpointLabelFilter
Classes/AWSLexGetSessionRequest.html#/c:.abstract:
A string used to filter the intents returned in the recentIntentSummaryView structure.

When you specify a filter, only intents with their checkpointLabel field set to that string are returned.

Classes/AWSLexGetSessionRequest.html#/c:.name: userId
Classes/AWSLexGetSessionRequest.html#/c:.abstract: The ID of the client application user. Amazon Lex uses this to identify a user’s conversation with your bot.

Classes/AWSLexGenericAttachment.html#/c:.name: attachmentLinkUrl
Classes/AWSLexGenericAttachment.html#/c:.abstract: The URL of an attachment to the response card.

Classes/AWSLexGenericAttachment.html#/c:.name: buttons
Classes/AWSLexGenericAttachment.html#/c:.abstract: The list of options to show to the user.

Classes/AWSLexGenericAttachment.html#/c:.name: imageUrl
Classes/AWSLexGenericAttachment.html#/c:.abstract: The URL of an image that is displayed to the user.

Classes/AWSLexDialogAction.html#/c:objc(.name: fulfillmentState
Classes/AWSLexDialogAction.html#/c:objc(.abstract:
The fulfillment state of the intent. The possible values are:

  • Failed - The Lambda function associated with the intent failed to fulfill the intent.

  • Fulfilled - The intent has fulfilled by the Lambda function associated with the intent.

  • ReadyForFulfillment - All of the information necessary for the intent is present and the intent ready to be fulfilled by the client application.

Classes/AWSLexDialogAction.html#/c:objc(.name: message
Classes/AWSLexDialogAction.html#/c:objc(.abstract: The message that should be shown to the user. If you don’t specify a message, Amazon Lex will use the message configured for the intent.

Classes/AWSLexDialogAction.html#/c:objc(.name: messageFormat
Classes/AWSLexDialogAction.html#/c:objc(.abstract:
• PlainText - The message contains plain UTF-8 text.

  • CustomPayload - The message is a custom format for the client.

  • SSML - The message contains text formatted for voice output.

  • Composite - The message contains an escaped JSON object containing one or more messages. For more information, see Message Groups.

Classes/AWSLexDialogAction.html#/c:objc(.name: slotToElicit
Classes/AWSLexDialogAction.html#/c:objc(.abstract: The name of the slot that should be elicited from the user.

Classes/AWSLexDialogAction.html#/c:objc(.name: slots
Classes/AWSLexDialogAction.html#/c:objc(.abstract: Map of the slots that have been gathered and their values.

Classes/AWSLexDialogAction.html#/c:objc(.name: types
Classes/AWSLexDialogAction.html#/c:objc(.abstract:
The next action that the bot should take in its interaction with the user. The possible values are:

  • ConfirmIntent - The next action is asking the user if the intent is complete and ready to be fulfilled. This is a yes/no question such as “Place the order?”

  • Close - Indicates that the there will not be a response from the user. For example, the statement “Your order has been placed” does not require a response.

  • Delegate - The next action is determined by Amazon Lex.

  • ElicitIntent - The next action is to determine the intent that the user wants to fulfill.

  • ElicitSlot - The next action is to elicit a slot value from the user.

Classes/AWSLexDeleteSessionResponse.html.name: botAlias
Classes/AWSLexDeleteSessionResponse.html.abstract: The alias in use for the bot associated with the session data.

Classes/AWSLexDeleteSessionResponse.html.name: botName
Classes/AWSLexDeleteSessionResponse.html.abstract: The name of the bot associated with the session data.

Classes/AWSLexDeleteSessionResponse.html.name: userId
Classes/AWSLexDeleteSessionResponse.html.abstract: The ID of the client application user.

Classes/AWSLexDeleteSessionRequest.html#.name: botAlias
Classes/AWSLexDeleteSessionRequest.html#.abstract: The alias in use for the bot that contains the session data.

Classes/AWSLexDeleteSessionRequest.html#.name: botName
Classes/AWSLexDeleteSessionRequest.html#.abstract: The name of the bot that contains the session data.

Classes/AWSLexDeleteSessionRequest.html#.name: userId
Classes/AWSLexDeleteSessionRequest.html#.abstract: The identifier of the user associated with the session data.

Classes/AWSLexButton.html#/c:objc(cs)AWS.name: text
Classes/AWSLexButton.html#/c:objc(cs)AWS.abstract: Text that is visible to the user on the button.

Classes/AWSLexButton.html#/c:objc(cs)AWS.name: value
Classes/AWSLexButton.html#/c:objc(cs)AWS.abstract: The value sent to Amazon Lex when a user chooses the button. For example, consider button text “NYC.” When the user chooses the button, the value sent can be “New York City.”

Classes/AWSLexAudioPlayer.html#/c:objc(c.name: completionBlock
Classes/AWSLexAudioPlayer.html#/c:objc(c.abstract: Set it to handle successful audio play.

Classes/AWSLexAudioPlayer.html#/c:objc(c.name: preparedBlock
Classes/AWSLexAudioPlayer.html#/c:objc(c.abstract: Set it to handle when audio has been prepared to play.

Classes/AWSLexAudioSession.html#/c:objc(.name: -overrideOutputAudioPort:
Classes/AWSLexAudioSession.html#/c:objc(.abstract: Override output audio port to AVAudioSessionPortOverrideSpeaker if headset is not detected.

Classes/AWSLexAudioSession.html#/c:objc(.name: -startObservingAudioSessionRouteChangeNotification
Classes/AWSLexAudioSession.html#/c:objc(.abstract: Start observing for AVAudioSessionRouteChangeNotification if not already started.

Classes/AWSLexSwitchModeInput.html#/c:ob.name: slots
Classes/AWSLexSwitchModeInput.html#/c:ob.abstract: The slots which are currently filled in an ongoing dialog

Classes/AWSLexSwitchModeInput.html#/c:ob.name: elicitSlot
Classes/AWSLexSwitchModeInput.html#/c:ob.abstract: The slot which is being ellicited for an intent.

Classes/AWSLexSwitchModeInput.html#/c:ob.name: sessionAttributes
Classes/AWSLexSwitchModeInput.html#/c:ob.abstract: The session attributes returned from the service.

Classes/AWSLexSwitchModeInput.html#/c:ob.name: audioStream
Classes/AWSLexSwitchModeInput.html#/c:ob.abstract: The audio stream . This may be null incase of a text response.

Classes/AWSLexSwitchModeInput.html#/c:ob.name: audioContentType
Classes/AWSLexSwitchModeInput.html#/c:ob.abstract: The format for the audio stream. This may be null if the audion stream is null.

Classes/AWSLexSwitchModeInput.html#/c:ob.name: inputTranscript
Classes/AWSLexSwitchModeInput.html#/c:ob.abstract: Transcript of the voice input to the operation.

Classes/AWSLexInteractionKit.html#/c:obj.name: +defaultInteractionKit
Classes/AWSLexInteractionKit.html#/c:obj.abstract: Returns the singleton interactionKit client. If the singleton object does not exist, the SDK instantiates the default service client with defaultServiceConfiguration from [AWSServiceManager defaultServiceManager]. The reference to this object is maintained by the SDK, and you do not need to retain it manually.

Classes/AWSLexInteractionKit.html#/c:obj.name: +registerInteractionKitWithServiceConfiguration:interactionKitConfiguration:forKey:
Classes/AWSLexInteractionKit.html#/c:obj.abstract: Creates a InteractionKit client with the given service configuration and registers it for the key.

Classes/AWSLexInteractionKit.html#/c:obj.name: +interactionKitForKey:
Classes/AWSLexInteractionKit.html#/c:obj.abstract: Retrieves the service client associated with the key. You need to call + registerLexWithConfiguration:forKey: before invoking this method.

Classes/AWSLexInteractionKit.html#/c:obj.name: +removeInteractionKitForKey:
Classes/AWSLexInteractionKit.html#/c:obj.abstract: Removes the interaction kit associated with the key and release it.

Classes/AWSLexInteractionKit.html#/c:obj.name: -textInTextOut:
Classes/AWSLexInteractionKit.html#/c:obj.abstract: Accepts a text input and responds back with a text output

Classes/AWSLexInteractionKit.html#/c:obj.name: -textInTextOut:sessionAttributes:
Classes/AWSLexInteractionKit.html#/c:obj.abstract: Accets a text input and an optional sessionAttribute dictionary and responds back with a text output.

Classes/AWSLexInteractionKit.html#/c:obj.name: -textInAudioOut:
Classes/AWSLexInteractionKit.html#/c:obj.abstract: Accepts a text input and responds back with an audio response. the playback will begin automatically unless you have set autoplayback to false in the InteractionKitConfig.

Classes/AWSLexInteractionKit.html#/c:obj.name: -textInAudioOut:sessionAttributes:
Classes/AWSLexInteractionKit.html#/c:obj.abstract: Accepts a text input and an optional sessionAttribute dictionary and responds back with an audio response. The playback will begin automatically unless you have set autoplayback to false in the InteractionKitConfig.

Classes/AWSLexInteractionKit.html#/c:obj.name: -audioInAudioOut
Classes/AWSLexInteractionKit.html#/c:obj.abstract: Starts the microphone and listens to audio from the phone microphone and responds back with an audio response.The playback will begin automatically unless you have set autoplayback to false in the InteractionKitConfig.

Classes/AWSLexInteractionKit.html#/c:obj.name: -audioInAudioOutWithSessionAttributes:
Classes/AWSLexInteractionKit.html#/c:obj.abstract: Starts the microphone and listens to audio from the phone microphone and responds back with an audio response.The playback will begin automatically unless you have set autoplayback to false in the InteractionKitConfig.

Classes/AWSLexInteractionKit.html#/c:obj.name: -audioInTextOut
Classes/AWSLexInteractionKit.html#/c:obj.abstract: Starts the microphone and listens to audio from the phone microphone and responds back with a text response.

Classes/AWSLexInteractionKit.html#/c:obj.name: -audioInTextOutWithSessionAttributes:
Classes/AWSLexInteractionKit.html#/c:obj.abstract: Starts the microphone and listens to audio from the phone microphone and responds back with a text response.

Classes/AWSLexInteractionKit.html#/c:obj.name: -cancel
Classes/AWSLexInteractionKit.html#/c:obj.abstract: Cancels ongoing http call and stops listening to Microphone if Audio input was requested.

Classes/AWSLexSwitchModeResponse.html.name: AWSLexSwitchModeResponse
Classes/AWSLexSwitchModeResponse.html.abstract: A response class returned back to the InteractionKit, In the course that user decides to switch modes of input between 2 requests, or set additional session attributes in the subsequant request.

Classes/AWSLexButton.html.name: AWSLexButton
Classes/AWSLexButton.html.abstract: Represents an option to be shown on the client platform (Facebook, Slack, etc.)

Classes/AWSLexDialogAction.html.name: AWSLexDialogAction
Classes/AWSLexDialogAction.html.abstract: Describes the next action that the bot should take in its interaction with the user and provides information about the context in which the action takes place. Use the DialogAction data type to set the interaction to a specific state, or to return the interaction to a previous state.

Classes/AWSLexGenericAttachment.html.name: AWSLexGenericAttachment
Classes/AWSLexGenericAttachment.html.abstract: Represents an option rendered to the user when a prompt is shown. It could be an image, a button, a link, or text.

Classes/AWSLexIntentSummary.html.name: AWSLexIntentSummary
Classes/AWSLexIntentSummary.html.abstract: Provides information about the state of an intent. You can use this information to get the current state of an intent so that you can process the intent, or so that you can return the intent to its previous state.

Classes/AWSLexResponseCard.html.name: AWSLexResponseCard
Classes/AWSLexResponseCard.html.abstract: If you configure a response card when creating your bots, Amazon Lex substitutes the session attributes and slot values that are available, and then returns it. The response card can also come from a Lambda function ( dialogCodeHook and fulfillmentActivity on an intent).

Classes/AWSLexSentimentResponse.html.name: AWSLexSentimentResponse
Classes/AWSLexSentimentResponse.html.abstract:
The sentiment expressed in an utterance.

When the bot is configured to send utterances to Amazon Comprehend for sentiment analysis, this field structure contains the result of the analysis.

Classes/AWSLex.html.name: AWSLex
Classes/AWSLex.html.abstract: Amazon Lex provides both build and runtime endpoints. Each endpoint provides a set of operations (API). Your conversational bot uses the runtime API to understand user utterances (user input text or voice). For example, suppose a user says “I want pizza”, your bot sends this input to Amazon Lex using the runtime API. Amazon Lex recognizes that the user request is for the OrderPizza intent (one of the intents defined in the bot). Then Amazon Lex engages in user conversation on behalf of the bot to elicit required information (slot values, such as pizza size and crust type), and then performs fulfillment activity (that you configured when you created the bot). You use the build-time API to create and manage your Amazon Lex bot. For a list of build-time operations, see the build-time API, .
